8.24.17  7:17 pm   How come when I listen to "Tell Me Something Good" (the Chaka Khan song)  I always lose track of where the beat is? I can tap my foot to the 'pulse', but when I try to count out the beat (1-2-3-4) I always get thrown off, like I'll think I know what to call "beat 1" but as the song goes on it seems like where I was counting beat 1 gets off place.

     i've only heard that song a couple of times but if i recall correctly the verses have sort of a backwards groove, i believe the clav (funk keyboard) is playing downbeats, in a way you would expect upbeats to be played. so it might be easy to hear the verse backwards. the top of the chorus is "Tell," and likely that part is easy to hear correctly. but the verse surely flipped you around. and the more you get to know the song from that perspective, the harder it will be to un-hear it that way

8.24.17  7:15 pm   i find the notion of being able to learn things and teaching yourself those things (and maybe others) so amazing that it makes me wanna cry and live forever. watcha think?

     i agree

8.24.17  6:14 pm   where did all the fidget spinners go?

8.24.17  6:00 pm   Hey, so I think you say that you usually write the melody and harmony of a song together... Just wondering where rhythm fits into this?

     melody has rhythm

      I guess a melody has its own implied rhythm. But do you usually write/record drums and bass last?

     drums and bass are not necessarily part of the writing. sometimes there will be hints at what's supposed to happen, but writing the song usually does not include deciding exactly what everyone is going to play. when it comes time to do the song, then the players (which all happen to be me) use their best judgement for how to do the song. it's like making a movie or tv show. the script mainly has dialogue, and some basic info about scenes and sets. but the writers don't build the sets, and they are not making decisions about every little item that goes everywhere on the set. that is done by the set designers, but they are doing it based on the way the script seems to imply it should be, even though the details may not be written in the script. they are using their judgement based on the what they can infer from the script

      Do you often switch it up, like a cool little rhythmic pattern pops up in your head and you think "oh, that needs a melody"?

     the vast majority of songwriting for me is based on the melody/lyric, but a small number of times i have found a certain groove or chord sequence that i think is basis for a song, so it is entered into the song list. i don't recall if any of those have ever made it to the next step
